data.title: Expect more rioting says Met Police chief
data.meta_description: VIOLENT protests are likely to increase as Britain braces itself for cuts to public services, the country’s top police chief warned yesterday.
data.text:
Sir Paul Stephenson, head of the Metropolitan Police, revealed that the nature of protests had changed and he expected more disorder.

The Commissioner admitted that his officers had failed to predict the change in mood among student demonstrators before the Millbank riot two weeks ago.

He said the violence, which saw protesters running amok at Conservative Party headquarters, illustrated his fear that “the game has changed”.

FOLLOW THE EXPRESS ON TWITTER!

He warned that police would make a more robust response to future protests, as they had on Wednesday when riot officers used controversial “kettling” tactics to hem in angry crowds.

Speaking at a meeting of the Metropolitan Police Authority, Sir Paul said: “We have been going through a period where we have not seen that sort of violent disorder.

“We had dealt with student organisers before and we based it too much on history. Regrettably, the game has changed and we must act.”

As Sir Paul issued his stark assessment, student groups involved in the National Campaign Against Fees and Cuts said they hoped more demonstrators would take to the streets next Tuesday.

There are also plans for a national day of action when the tuition fees bill is debated in Parliament, probably next month.

Wednesday’s demonstration, which included many school pupils, was contained in Whitehall, near the entrance to Downing Street, where about 5,000 demonstrators were corralled for several hours.

Sir Paul said that when several marches linked up in Whitehall, the police’s aim had been to stop them getting into Parliament Square.

As a result the damage caused was far more limited than in the previous protest.

Sir Paul said: “We put a lot more assets out but we got it right.”

Speaking about the decision to pen in protesters, Sir Paul said there were fears some would try to occupy the Liberal Democrat headquarters in Westminster.

He added: “There was no doubt if protesters were given free reign they would have tried to enter premises by force.”

Sir Paul said police wanted to release the penned-in demonstrators earlier, but were not able to because of renewed clashes outside the area. But student spokesman Simon Hardy told a press conference: “The police actions were absolutely outrageous.

“Children as young as 13, 14, or 15 were not allowed to leave and were intimidated by hundreds of riot police and treated very badly when all they were doing was exercising their democratic right to protest.”
